title: Do native English speakers make grammatical mistakes while speaking or writing? - Quora

response.answer_text: Absolutely. They're typically just different from the non-native speakers. (First, you have to put aside various non-standard dialects--as one or two others mentioned here already, those aren't technically mistakes, just non-standard. English is made up of these dialects; it's just that one or two were standardized and made canon at some point in history. You also find a number of differences between, say, British and American English--at the weekend and on the weekend, for example, or in hospital and in the hospital. That's not what we're talking about. I'm also going to put aside punctuation and other writing-specific errors and focus on oral communication.) Errors--and by error I mean systematic ones that normally educated native speakers of the standard dialect frequently make--tend to be quite different. High-level English learner errors that native speakers would never make: Tense confusion, depending on the origin language. French and Italian speakers tend to say, "I have gone to that movie yesterday." A German speaker might say, "I am always reading the newspaper every morning." Everyone tends to overuse the past perfect--"I had gone to school last week and had done all my homework." (with no context that would trigger the past perfect, such as "...before I dropped out and burned my books.") Native speakers rarely select the wrong tense.Modal confusion: "Tonight I will go home early because I must study." This is fine for communicative purposes, as any native speaker would understand immediately what is being said, but no native speaker would normally phrase it this way. We would probably say, "Tonight I'm going home early because I have to study," or "Tonight I'm going to go home early because I've got to study."Prepositions, phrasal verbs, and articles. They're idiomatic and tough. Native speakers tend not to have problems with these.Native speakers, on the other hand, frequently make these mistakes... Confusing the three principal parts of irregular verbs--"drink, drank, drunk," for example, or "lie, lay, lain." Non-native speakers learn right off the bat that the second part is for the past simple and that the third (participle) goes after "to be" in the passive or "to have" in the perfect tenses. "I have drank," is incorrect but common. "I'm going to lay on my bed," is another. (Non-native speakers may also make these mistakes, depending on their level, but they tend to shed these errors as they become advanced, knowing the rules behind them.)Confusing elements that are phonetically similar: e.g. "could've" rendered "could of" in writing and then in turn in speech. A non-native speaker probably wouldn't do this because it just doesn't make any sense semantically, and they're more aware of each word that they say than your average native speaker.Subjunctive and conditional errors. "If I was rich" should be "If I were rich" and "If I would have known..." should be "If I had known." The subjunctive is dying, and the correct formation of a conditional sentence is starting to falter as well. (non-native speakers may also make these mistakes, because conditionals are a little complicated.)Double negatives--"I wouldn't know nothing about that"--but these tend to be a lot rarer among educated native speakers and frequently associated with a lack of education. (You also find these among non-natives speakers.)Lack of awareness of countable and uncountable nouns: e.g. "There were less people there" instead of "There were fewer people there." However, a native speaker would never refer to "informations" as non-native speakers frequently do.Adverb/adjective confusion: "I'm good." "I feel badly about that."Subject/object confusion--not just the distinction between whom and who, which is now so rare that most ESL books cite whom as optional, but also subject/object pronouns: "This picture is of my husband and I at the Grand Canyon."Of course, most of these mistakes might also be made by non-native speakers, especially at lower and intermediate levels--but as I said before, non-native speakers tend to be made more aware of them through ESOL classes and instruction. They are, for the most part, actively seeking to eliminate errors from their usage in a way that native speakers usually aren't. It is, however, difficult to get to the point in a foreign language (as an adult) at which one makes ZERO mistakes, especially when it comes to prepositions and more complex sentences, and especially in speaking, when one doesn't have the luxury of leisurely revision. On the other hand, if a non-native speaker isn't studying but picking up the language organically (as most low-income immigrants do), they will probably pick up the language that is being spoken around them, which might include many of the above mistakes.

Yes, and in two completely different ways. Most of the existing answers seem to assume only one class of mistake: non-conformance to prescriptivist grammar as taught in schools. But the thing is, any particular class can only teach the rules of one dialect at a time (and those in England will teach things slightly differently from those in the U.S., for example). Given the number of different English dialects in existence, it doesn't matter which one you pick; the vast majority of native English speakers will not natively speak that dialect. And if you judge the correctness of someone's speech by the rules of someone else's dialect, they will get a lot of things wrong. So, yes, native English speakers make mistakes in non-native dialects, including standard taught-in-school dialects, all the freaking time. By this standard, non-native speakers may indeed be observed to make fewer errors than natives, since they will have learned the standard dialect against which everyone is being judged. It's important to note, however, that what looks like a mistake compared to some standard dialect is almost always not actually a mistake to the person speaking. For example, when you come across a Utahan saying something like "I might could've done it" (absolutely right out according to high school English and ESL classes the world over- English doesn't have serial verb constructions!), or a speaker of African American Vernacular saying something like "I be runnin in the mornings", they are not making a mistake. They meant to say it that way, it is perfectly understandable to their peers, and it is correct according to the rules of their native dialect. There is a second kind of error, though. Ignoring issues of standardization and dialectal variation, mentally normal, non-speech-impaired people do make mistakes in their own native dialects fairly frequently. I.e., they say things that they themselves retroactively identify as incorrect. And this happens in every language. The reasons are quite varied, and observing what kinds of errors people do and do not make tells us quite a bit about how language is produced in the brain. In writing, for example, substitution of homophones is quite common (e.g., writing "there" for "they're" or "their"). In speaking, things like swapping inflectional endings between words (like "I'm start to thinking" for "I'm starting to think") or incorrect verb agreement (usually a result of long sentences where the speaker loses track, or changes their mind about what they wanted to say half-way through) are fairly common.

Yes. Many native speakers of English dash off dangling modifiers as if they were going out of fashion. They occur far more in writing than in speech, and are among the reasons why proofreaders and sub-editors gnash their teeth down to the stumps. They’re annoying because they can’t be easily corrected like simple typos or poor subject-verb agreement; they require rewriting of whole sentences, standfirsts (they’re ever so popular in standfirsts) and, sometimes, entire paragraphs. I may have altered the nouns, adjectives and verbs to protect the guilty, but these are close-enough examples of some of the lines I’ve had to deal with from people whose first language is supposed to be English: • “Featuring floor-to-ceiling windows and magnificent chandeliers, you and your wedding guests will love this grand ballroom.” • “Sprinting up the road, the castle was on fire.” • “Jointly held by Ivan the Terrible and Tamberlaine the Great, this is an ideal venue for a party that will culminate in a massacre.” • “Waking up at three in the morning, the room was in darkness.” • “Lovingly assembled from precious metal parts and set with diamonds, fashionistas will love these vintage watches.” • “Reading a murder mystery, the cat began to hiss furiously and back away from my armchair.” These grammatical errors crop up again and again like never-say-die zombies. So I keep getting brides, bridegrooms and wedding guests who feature floor-to-ceiling windows and magnificent chandeliers; castles that run (whose castle is this? Howl’s?); people holding a venue rather than an event; rooms that wake up at three in the morning; fashion lovers assembled from gold parts; and cats who read murder mysteries. I suppose I do have to earn my keep. And if the murder mystery the cat was reading had dangling modifiers in it, well, that would be good – kitties like dangling things, don’t they?

Of course we do. We have standard mistakes like mixing up fewer with less, and lately I hear a lot of native speakers not using past participles in verb structures: I should have went when the correct usage is I should have gone. These two instances may be examples of change where it may be a matter of time before few and its comparative fewer and fewest disappear along with irregular past participles. Usage rules, as they say. Here’s one that is always a written problem for native speakers of English: it’s versus its. English shows possessive case by adding ‘s to nouns. Carol’s friend. Possessive pronouns can take the place of the noun: Her friend. The confusion comes in with third person it. I like it. It’s delicious. The it’s is not a possessive pronoun but rather a contraction of it is. So: I like it. It’s delicious and its texture is quite nice too. You can see this error everywhere - in signs, in newspapers, text books, and on tv.

Even some of the most highly educated native speakers make mistakes with the subjunctive: using it when they shouldn’t! For example, here’s a quote from a linguistics paper published at Indiana University: “ . . . if Old English /r/ were dorsal, then perhaps Germanic /r/ also was.” This should be “. . . if Old Enlgish /r/ was dorsal . . . .” This error seems to come from some misguided belief that one should always use “were” rather than “was” in an if clause. Bad English teachers are probably to blame for this. “Were” should be used instead of “was” in an if clause only when expressing something that is known to be contrary to fact, not when there may be some doubt about factuality.

Of course they make mistakes. But they are not the same mistakes that a learner of English as a foreign language would make. Rather, they are considered a lower class of dialect. Mistakes are due to a lack of education, laziness and imitating other speakers who use bad English. Popular songs contain these mistakes and they follow clear patterns.  Not every mistake affects the understanding. If they are common errors we pick them out right away and our mind comes up with the correct version.  The problems get worse when one doesn't know express his thoughts in a clear and orderly fashion. Bad syntax can render a sentence incomprehensible. Run on sentences are a serious problem. Using the incorrect word can be a serious error. That often happens when a person tries to use a word he does not really know.  Generally the errors of a native speaker do not impede understanding while the errors of a learner of English can be more serious

As a native English speaker, I find that native English speakers make more grammatical mistakes than a lot of non-native speakers. In written English, natives tend to be even worse. My theory is that this is because often non-native speakers put a lot more effort into learning our arcane grammatical rules than native speakers do. This is because native speakers learn most of our English informally, and often do not think much about whether we are using it correctly. I have found that often, young Germans have a command of written and spoken English that puts young British people to shame. I think this is partly because our shared heritage, and English's German roots, gives Germans a particular sprachgefühl (feeling for the language) for English.

For the most part, the more ephemeral the communication, the more likely it is to have mistakes in it.  If I write a text, or a reply such as this one, or an email, and can't edit it after I send it, then geez, people make mistakes.  Or we purposely write in an informal manner, to mimic how we might speak.  Speaking grammatically correctly all of the time gets one labeled as a prude. More permanent works, such as a resume, a book, or an article, well, we expect more diligence for those.  More proofreading, rewriting, even having someone else proofread for you.  The standards are higher the longer lasting the work is. This is not a particularly formal setting, so please forgive the informality and errors in the preceding.  ;-)

Yes and they do mostly not only for non-english speakers sometimes, for the most of us proper english is quite challenging when we convey upon to the society we live in, and context wouldn’t be essential as we AIN’T feeling realistic of every situations and writings, but it other sense when you learn it from movies and musics, that's when fluency starts to make it so prevalent than grammar which it's not realistic, but although they don't even care about unlike some they do it genuinely, but we are not perfect like I would say we was not perfect, if you want it as your main or 2ndary language, then don't be fret about it because that's what everyone says in their quotes or yeah everyone embrace it cause we're not perfect.

Yep. We do…alot of times when we are in a hurry and don't pay attention to what autocorrect is doing to or work. We end sentences with ellipsis points because we want to… And we begin sentences with and. We are horribly guilty of misplacing, misusing, overusing, and never replacing commas, therefore we neglect semicolons, often to embarrassing degrees. So their. Its the best we can do in the mobile device age.

It often seems to me that most of the non-native English speakers I know have better grammar than those who are native speakers. I don't know how it's possible to only speak one language and still not know the difference between "your" and "you're," or "to," "too," and "two," yet native speakers make these mistakes consistently, while those who learned English as a second language usually seem to get it right. Maybe they put more emphasis on learning the grammar rules correctly? The most common mistake I see non-native speakers make is unusual word order, but if they are reasonably fluent then their grammar is pretty impeccable.

Only all the time. In recent decades there's been increasing resistance to the idea that English has one proper grammar. I know teachers who do not use correct grammar and if they don't, who else can? And in these modern times, children resist learning grammar. Speaking any language correctly requires some effort and concentration and children in the U.S find it hard to settle, focus and concentrate.

Oh good grief yes.  Just have a look at any news article posted online and I might be able to guarantee that there are errors.  Native English speakers does not mean "perfect" English speakers. Heck, spelling errors are one of the worst offenses for anyone.

Yes! All native English speakers make grammatical mistakes while speaking, and a good 50% make mistakes while writing. If I were to knock on your door, and you ask, “Who is it?”, I would reply, “It's me!”. Now; to be grammatically correct, I should answer, “It is I!”, but no. I reply “It's me!”.

Just think of this: As a native speaker of your mother tongue, do you use grammatically correct sentences all the time? Do people around you (also native speakers) speak and write correctly all the time? It's the same everywhere. Not even natives have complete mastery of their own language.

As a non-native speaker of English lang. I'd say that no body is perfect n all have mistakes n it's possible that the native speakers do that kinda gaffs more than non-native speakers do! Cuz maybe they learnt thier lang. informal so when they speak they dont pay great attention to wat 's said than wat should be said ! Anyway, i myself sometimes do that mistakes with my mother tongue ARABIC LANG. Especially me since i study , learn n speak English almost all the time n i use Arabic rarely these days n this is makes me do mistakes in my mother tongue . So it quite normal thing ; )
Yes. Many native English speakers don't know when to properly use "who" and "whom."  I also see a lot people use "would of"  instead of "would have."  Major pet peeves for  this grammar Nazi.

All the time, even on national news broadcasts. Very few people speak and especially write English with low numbers of mistakes. I even catch myself making mistakes from time to time, if I'm not paying attention.
Thanks for the A2A.  Yes, native English speakers make grammatical errors all the time.  See, for example, speakers of so-called Ebonics.
Yes. I make more when speaking than when writing. It’s not that I’m unaware of the correct syntax. It’s about habit and dialect.
